keyTakeAways: Western sanctions have significantly damaged Iran's economy, particularly impacting the middle class that historically drove political reform and stability.
The Iranian middle class, long a force for moderation and political engagement, has shrunk by 28% between 2012 and 2019 due to sanctions, according to a synthetic control study.
A 2025 IMF-reported inflation rate of 42.4% and rising prices of basic goods (e.g., rice) have made daily living extremely difficult for lower-income Iranians.
The unemployment rate in Iran is estimated at 7.4% (Statistical Center) to 9.2% (IMF), with youth and educated professionals like Ali facing limited job opportunities.
Sanctions have funneled economic benefits to state-linked institutions like the IRGC and bonyads, while weakening independent civil society and entrepreneurship.
The political landscape has shifted from middle-class demands for reform to working-class demands for survival, increasing volatility and state repression risks.
The perception of inequality is more dangerous than actual inequality, threatening national unity and long-term stability.
Without a generational reset, rebuilding the Iranian middle class is considered a long-term, difficult process even if sanctions are lifted.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Western sanctions on Iran, particularly intensified from 2012 onward, have significantly harmed the country’s middle class—historically a driving force behind political reform and social stability. A study in the European Journal of Political Economy using a synthetic control method reveals that without sanctions, Iran’s middle class would have grown by 17% between 2012 and 2019, but instead shrank by 28%. Rising inflation, unemployment (up to 9.2%), and soaring prices of basic goods have made daily life difficult, especially for young, educated professionals. Sanctions have funneled economic benefits to state-linked institutions like the IRGC and bonyads, weakening civil society and entrepreneurship. This has shifted political engagement from demands for reform to cries for survival, increasing social fragmentation and vulnerability to repression. As a result, Iran faces a deepening wealth gap, a shrinking middle class, and an unstable political landscape, with experts warning that rebuilding the middle class is a generational challenge.
title: How Western sanctions on Iran have hurt the same middle class that drives reform
